title: University initiations leave over a third of sixth form students at top schools feeling anxious
text:
University initiations leave over a third of top sixth form students feeling anxious before freshers’ week, a poll has found.

Some 38 per cent of pupils aged 16-18 at the country’s leading public schools said they are either concerned or nervous about initiation rituals, according to a survey of 2,815 pupils.

A report, published by the Headmasters’ and Headmistresses’ Conference (HMC) and the Girls’ School Association (GSA), also found that around a quarter of sixth form students were worried about their social life at university.

Chris Ramsey, co-chair of the HMC’s universities committee, said: “Over the last few years everyone’s become a bit more open about things. There has been a lot of publicity about initiation ceremonies, particularly in sports clubs and the likes.”

He said school pupils have “heard stories about things that might happen” during initiations, and that it’s “not something they want to be part of”.

Mr Ramsey, who is headmaster of Whitgift School which charges £40,140-a-year for boarders, explained that students these days have a “great deal of common sense”.

“What we’re seeing is a much more level-headed student population, which is interested in university for the right reasons, and really turning away from the kind of excesses of student behaviour that we all used to think happened,” he said.
